Haulingboat

I am propossing in this thread that one can determine the political leanings of another person simply by listening to (in this case reading) their words. I do not mean during politics discussions or when covering topics that fall under one political persuasion or the other. I mean by taking the discussion beyond the original meaning and discovering the thought processes behind the words.
 
 Here is an example. I hope it sheds some light on my point and makes my stance easier to understand.
 
 Here is billsco's signature:
 
 When I asked my boss for a raise he said I was expendable. When I asked for the day off he said I was indispensable. - 
 
 At first read it gives one a chuckle. It displays the irony of the working mans boss in a comical manner.
 
 I believe there is an underlieing sentiment of liberalism in this statement. I contest that it displays Billsco's dependance on his boss to GRANT him more money or more time off. That Billsco can relate the this statement because he works a job with a scenario similar to this. The statement and Billsco's real life connect in some way allowing him to understand and "get" the joke. This connects better with people of the same situation.
 
 I believe that a person of the conservative pursasion would say to themselves, "Why doesn't he go make a buck on his own accord. Then he could grant himself a day off whenever he needed it." I contest that this statement displays self-relience and a conservative-mindedness, an attitude that might take some of the punch out of the punchline. One that republicans can connect with easier.
 
 I mean not to pick on Billsco at all. In fact I appoligize to him for making an example of his signature. I believe there are many of these statments uttered daily by people in normal conversation that reveal their political persuasion. They say alot about ones mindset, values, and beliefs without the intent of doing so. 
 
 What do you think? Am I way off base here or does this sound logical?
pnac=ww3

Let's not confuse conservative/liberal with Rep/Dem, please. It's really not the same at all.
 
 Just because someone doesn't own his own business doesn't mean they are not conservative. And conversely, just because someone has a boss doesn't mean they are liberal.
 
 All you may be saying is that there is a correlation to what people say and their beliefs. That's not much of a stretch, but actually determining what their beliefs are based on what they say is what most people do sub(un)consciously all the time.
 
 Also, most of us ASSUME another's beliefs after hearing them say this or that, but we could be dead wrong. 
 
 Which (if either) do you think I am?
 
 If I had to guess, you like to think of yourself as conservative, based on the positive attributes (self-reliance) you gave to being such. At the same time, the way you talked about billsco's signature made me think that the first time you read it, you thought about him as a liberal.
Duo_Maxwell

Haulingboat: Bill might just think that is funny. I could have posted a link to a comic on Clinton regarding the Mcgreevy incident. That doesn't make me a democrat nor a republic, or a liberal or a conservative. It simply means I enjoy some good humor. Humocrat? Or Repubmor? Take your pick. Or maybe a libmor or humative? 
 
 Republicans are not conservatives for the most part and democrats aren't liberals for the most part.
Famous Amos

Republicans are not conservatives for the most part and democrats aren't liberals for the most part.

 
 
 Is this a joke? At least for politicians, nearly ALL Republicans lean more towards conservatism, and nearly ALL Democracts lean more towards liberalism. Take a look. George Bush, Trent Lott, Newt Gingrich, Dick Cheney, Dick Armey, etc are ALL Republicans, and ALL lean more towards the right. John Kerry, John Edwards, Hillary Clinton, Ted Kennedy, Tom Harkin, Wesley Clark, Dennis Kucinich, etc are all Democrats, and ALL lean more towards the left. 
 
 Now you may be true about the general public. Not all citizens who consider themselves Republicans are necessarily Conservatives, and not all citizens who consider themselves Democrats are necessarily Liberals.
jim's trucking

Not really.
 
 Listening to someone's words does not give as much insight into their political feelings as does noting what they do. Explore their history and you will find the key to unveiling their political views.
 
 People will say just about anything, as some political candidates do. (Actually MOST of them will at times say things just to please the audience.)
 
 Your analysis of Billsco's signature is unfounded. I have no doubt that liberals and conservatives alike have a similar attitude toward a miserly boss. You seem to imply that only liberals would think that way.
 
 Just because conservatives believe in nurturing capitalism doesn't mean they think everybody should be self-employed.
 
 ...

 What Jim's Trucking said.
 
 I think you're treading on really thin ice when you try to pigeon hole someone based on something as trivial as in your example using Billsco.
 
 Further to that, IMHO, the entire process of trying to brand people or lump them into generalized categories is a risky business.
 
 Waxy
Haulingboat

I am not afraid to admit when I am wrong. Perhaps my theory does not hold water. 
 I do believe that if you have an ability to read people you are "pigeon holing" them. I don't see this as a bad thing. I believe your political affiliations are directly connected to your morals and values. I also believe that you allow this things to shine through unconciously in daily conversasions. Thus making my point at least somewhat truthful.

 Haulingboat: I had the same though when I read the signature. However, that's not to say that I'd "treat" him that way based on my first reaction. But it's certainly a thought that crossed my mind initially. It's like "profiling". I think it's a good survival instinct, but I'm betting the reality is that it's not always a good indicator. Interesting thought though, I wonder if there are any studies on things similar to this.
 
 -Mach
syklopps61

It's like "profiling". I think it's a good survival instinct,

 
 Mach,
 I know this is off the topic but I just couldn't help myself-now, this is a legitimate question without sarcasm. If profiling is a good survival instinct, does that mean you support profiling of terrorists? Maybe somewhere in all your posts you have said this
Duo_Maxwell

Is this a joke? At least for politicians, nearly ALL Republicans lean more towards conservatism,

 
 But what they believe is conservatism isn't true to the historical platform. Many Republicans LOVE pork, which is the anti-thesis to conservative fiscal policies, needless spending that does not serve a great purpose beyond getting them re-elected. Or how about gay marriage? Which is a major step aganist state's rights, which many conservatives say they believe, yet attack. 
 
 

 and nearly ALL Democracts lean more towards liberalism.

 
 Depends. A liberal is anyone who disagrees with the rank and file notions of the Republican party. McCain is called a liberal by fellow Republicans. Liberalism is a use all term that has means nothing and everything at the same time. Support state's rights on gay marriage and you will be labeled a liberal. Attack Bush's liberal fiscal policies and you will be labeled a liberal. Attack Bush's disregard of conservative global alliances and you will be labeled a liberal. Modern liberalism bears virtually no resemblance to it's origin, and neither does Conservatism. 
 
 
Take a look. George Bush, Trent Lott, Newt Gingrich, Dick Cheney, Dick Armey, etc are ALL Republicans, and ALL lean more towards the right.

 
 I fail to see how Bush or Cheney do. Bush has shown in the past 3 years to be a hardcore liberal with money, (not to mention all his business ventures), not to mention shoving socialist policies left and right through congress. He's also presided over the biggest government since WWII, as well as attacking state's rights. Cheney has attacked strong defense for YEARS, calling to cut the F-16, F-15, F-14, M-1 Abram, Apache, and numerous other weapons. 
 
 

 John Kerry, John Edwards, Hillary Clinton, Ted Kennedy, Tom Harkin, Wesley Clark, Dennis Kucinich, etc are all Democrats, and ALL lean more towards the left. 

 
 Kucinich is a idiot. What do you consider left?
syklopps61

Or how about gay marriage? Which is a major step aganist state's rights, which many conservatives say they believe, yet attack. 

 
 C'mon, we all know the problem with gay marriage being left up to the States is that one State is going to make it legal and another ISN'T...And we all know that the whacked out activists, like a snot nosed teenager defying and testing authority, will move ON PURPOSE to a state that does NOT recognize their right to be married....and guess where they will take it? That's right, the Supreme Court. If these XXXXXX would grow up and stay in California or Massachusetts, I'd say fine, let the States decide 
 
 
A liberal is anyone who disagrees with the rank and file notions of the Republican party. 
 
 
 And what was Miller called by Carter (and you no doubt, at least offline)? C'mon, quit being a hypocrite, you Liberals felt that Jim Jeffries was a man of conscience and principle when he jumped to your side. But when Miller has opposing views, he is raked over the coals by your patron saint of Liberalism (Carter)
Mach

Mach,
 I know this is off the topic but I just couldn't help myself-now, this is a legitimate question without sarcasm. If profiling is a good survival instinct, does that mean you support profiling of terrorists? Maybe somewhere in all your posts you have said this

 
 It could be treated differently IMO because political predisposition doesn't carrry the negative and potentially criminal connotations that "susepcted terrorist" does. It is, of course, a natural instinct to use your "best guess". Stereotyping plays of this, so does, to some degree, predjudice. However, we are rational and can choose to override our instincts, and in general, I think, being "civilized" comes to down overriding such instincts when they do harm to society. And society defines what causes harm, it's nowhere near an absolute sort of thing.
 
 That being said, I do not know how we can NOT racially profile in some circumstances, but certainly not all situations require it. I think doing it in public...i.e. at the airport, would be less appropriate than say, doing background checks based on where you're from and if you just came to the country, etc. To be efficient, I think some forms of racial profiling are probably necessary as long as we're getting terrorized by specific nationalities and not the vast majority of others. That is, if we're having bandwidth issues on intelligence. If we aren't, then profiling is just being lazy (I suspect we have huge bandwidth issues!).
 
 -Mach
syklopps61

It is, of course, a natural instinct to use your "best guess". Stereotyping plays of this, so does, to some degree, predjudice. However, we are rational and can choose to override our instincts, and in general, I think, being "civilized" comes to down overriding such instincts when they do harm to society.

 
 Well, we ARE what we ARE...human. And we DO have survival instincts, and this is what I think is so laughable about the Left and to me supports the accusations that they are intellectually arrogant, feeling that they are above others, and apparently their own humanity. They have achieved a level of rational thought that us simpletons could never hope to achieve, and therefore we are to turn to them for guidance. Why should a survival instinct have to be overridden..I mean, it IS for survival, isn't it? Preventing HARM to a society is more important than the SURVIVAL of a society? GEEEZ it's considered uncivilized to eat like a pig, but when one is starving it can be overlooked. You can live again to eat the civilized way. The protection of the rights of these "people" could result in the destruction of our society, then there won't be anything to preserve. Seems to me you survive FIRST, THEN worry about someone's rights being stepped on
